conclusion: Analyze the thermodynamic cycle using the ideal gas law to find temperature at state C.
The image shows a thermodynamic cycle ABCDA on a P-V diagram with processes AB, BC, CD, and DA.
The behavior of the ideal gas is governed by the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
At state A, pressure is P1 and volume is V1. At state B, pressure is P2 and volume is V1. Temperature at B is T0.
At state C, pressure is P2 and volume is V2. Temperature at C is calculated as: TC = P2V2/nR.
At state D, pressure is P1 and volume is V2. Temperature at D is: TD = P1V2/nR.
Since the cycle is closed, net change in internal energy is zero, implying TC = TD.
Temperature at state C is: TC = TD = P1V2/nR.
Given T0 = P1V1/nR, find TC as: TC = (V2/V1) x T0.
